Author: CrisF#3405
Content:
Hi,
Is it normal for a z-sendmany to also send a small amount to a t-address?  (Doesn't seem to be a good thing at all)
I just did a z_send many to an empty wallet and the result was ```{
  "transparent": "0.00005",
  "interest": "0.00",
  "private": "1.0002",
  "total": "1.00025"
}
```

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: The transparent balance appeared immediately after the send.

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: I am mining on the receiving chain, but it is a 0 reward chain.

Author: CrisF#3405
Content:
```getreceivedbyaccount ""
0.00000000```

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: Is there a way to find out where the `0.00005` came from?

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Probably from a utxo that was paying the txfee

Author: Biz#0842
Content: Anyone have any experience with dual keypairs (like in BLUR or *cough* XMR), and what happens if two addresses were to share the same viewkey but not spendkey, or vice versa?

Author: Biz#0842
Content: Asking for a friend

Author: Biz#0842
Content: Just kidding, asking for my purposes

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Very little ,  what are you concerned with happening?

Author: Biz#0842
Content: Not sure. Just seems like something that might cause weird effects, like being able to have an address that has multiple viewkeys which converge to a single transactional record, or different addresses being able to spend from each other

Author: Biz#0842
Content: In BLUR addresses, for example, this would constitute the first or second half of an address being different, but the other half being identical to another address

Author: Biz#0842
Content: I just generated 64 addresses with the same spendkey, but a single wallet isnâ€™t receiving all of the transactions, and canâ€™t see all of them either. So, technically the spendkey has funds, but the wallet canâ€™t see the transfers it lacks the viewkey to

Author: Biz#0842
Content: Which seems to mean that any given BLUR or XMR address may in fact be able to spend someone elseâ€™s funds (without being able to see these in the wallet)

Author: Biz#0842
Content: Provided that the spendkeys converge, I mean

Author: Biz#0842
Content: Note: these 64 addresses all have different viewkeys

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Seems more of a user issue of bad key management than something intrinsically wrong with the protocol.   Doesnâ€™t seem out of place,  more like a tautology , a user with a spendkey for addresses A B and C can spend from addresses A.B. and C.

Author: Biz#0842
Content: Wasnâ€™t claiming itâ€™s an issue with the protocol. The issue would be within application of an existing technology, anyway. Asking out of intrigue mostly

Author: Biz#0842
Content: Monero uses deterministic keypairs, so this wouldnâ€™t happen under normal conditions unless something in the RNG was biased

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @CrisF just look at the txid on an explorer

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @CrisF also, did you send from a taddr or zaddr ?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: Change rules "change", depending on the transaction type

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: taddr change flows to a new taddr, zaddr change flows back to same zaddr

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: t=>(z,t) will leave behind some transparent change, that is probably what you did

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: t sending to z, with taddr change

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: like @polycryptoblog described, but I guess I wanted to explain more

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @polycryptoblog in BTC, if half of your privkey just happens to be half my privkey, there is no loss of privacy. But I think @Biz is saying that if something like that happened in XMR, you could view transactions you shouldn't.  The thing is, what are the chances and will it happen before the end of time?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: 2^64 is not super big, it might be more likely than XMR devs would like
